title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.34-36 | 11-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Mirandasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshuron Meelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and the Lord.

segments.key_quote: So Krishna's appearance, one of the reasons for his appearance is to reduce the burden of the Earth which is overburdened by demoniac persons posing as Kshatriyas.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verses to be discussed (SB 1.16.34-36) and begins explaining verse 34, focusing on the Earth being burdened by atheistic kings and the Lord's incarnation to relieve this burden.

segments.key_quote: They take charge or control of the whole state or province or country or whatever, and they create havoc in the lives of ordinary people.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the qualities of these 'demoniac' leaders, their lack of Kshatriya qualities, and how they create suffering for ordinary people, necessitating the Lord's intervention.

segments.key_quote: the Asuras want to enjoy life of sense gratification even at the cost of others happiness they don't care for others happiness and they also don't hesitate to give trouble to others who want to live a pious life
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the Lord's appearance through internal energy with ordinary births and quotes Srila Prabhupada on the nature of Asuras, their desire for sense gratification, and their tendency to create war.

segments.key_quote: mother earth because she considers all the living entities on living in this earth planet as her own children so she feels for their suffering when the Kings oppress the people
segments.summary: The speaker continues discussing the Asuras' tendency to create war and the suffering it causes, emphasizing Mother Earth's compassion and the Lord's duty to protect devotees and vanquish demons.

segments.key_quote: who therefore can tolerate the pangs of separation from that supreme personality of godhead
segments.summary: The speaker transitions to verse 35, focusing on the pain of separation from the Lord and the joy Mother Earth felt from the touch of His lotus feet.

segments.key_quote: So no chance of separation for Mother Earth from the contact with the lotus feet of the Supreme Lord Krishna when he was present on the earth.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the constant contact between the Lord's lotus feet and the Earth, contrasting it with the occasional separation felt by the Lord's queens.

segments.key_quote: While the earth and the personality of religion were thus engaged in conversation, the saintly king Pariksit reached the shore of the Saraswati river which flowed towards the east.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the intense feeling of separation Mother Earth experienced when the Lord departed and introduces verse 36, describing King Pariksit's arrival at the scene where Kali was mistreating a cow and bull, setting the stage for the next chapter.
